questions.text: You are working as a medical officer in a ceramic factory. What particle size of the dust inhaled would you be most concerned about?
questions.solution: Inhalation of dust particles in the size range of 0.5 to 3 microns is considered to be the most dangerous. It can lead to various occupational lung diseases called pneumoconioses.

questions.text:
Match the following causative agents with the disease caused by them:
  Dust particle    Disease
1. Coal dust a. Bagassosis
2. Hay dust b. Anthracosis
3. Cotton fibre c. Farmer's lung
4. Cane fiber d. Byssinosis
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

  • Coal dust - Anthracosis
  • Hay dust - Farmer's lung
  • Cotton fibre - Byssinosis
  • Cane fibre - Baggasosis

questions.text: While working as an MO, you noticed an increased number of bagassosis patients in the area. Which of the following fungal control measures would you advise the sugarcane farmers to implement?
questions.solution:
Fungal control on bagasse can be done by using 2% propionic acid and keeping the moisture content above 20%.

Bagassosis is a hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by inhaling bagasse dust contaminated by the fungus Thermoactinomyces sacchari. It is a reaction to the various antigens present in sugarcane molasses.

questions.text: A shipyard worker is diagnosed with asbestosis. Which of the following is false about his condition?

choices.text: The symptoms usually occur after 5-10 years of exposure
Peribronchial fibrosis is a characteristic finding
The most dangerous form of asbestos is chrysolite type

questions.solution:
Amphibole is the most dangerous form of asbestos. Chrysolite is a safer form of asbestos compared to amphibole.

Asbestosis is a pneumoconiosis that occurs after 5-10 years of exposure to asbestos. It progresses even after the removal of contact with asbestos. Asbestosis affects the basal part of the lung causing diffuse peribronchial fibrosis.

Sputum shows asbestos bodies, which are asbestos fibers coated with fibrin. The image given below shows asbestos bodies:

The complications that can occur are:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis 
  • Carcinoma of the lung 
  • Mesothelioma of the pleura
  • Malignancy of the gastrointestinal tract

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal colic and constipation. On examination, pallor and blue stippled lines on gums are observed. What is the most common mode of exposure to this particular toxicity?
questions.solution:
A patient presenting with constipation, pallor, and Burton's lines (blue stippled lines on gums), most likely has lead poisoning. The most common mode of exposure to lead toxicity is the inhalation of lead fumes. 

Lead poisoning occurs by lead exposure via the following modes:

  • Inhalation- lead fumes in gasoline and petroleum products
  • Ingestion- lead paint
  • Absorption through the skin– seen only with organic leads

The most toxic forms of lead are lead oxide, lead carbonate, and lead arsenate. The least toxic form is lead sulfide.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about lead poisoning?

choices.text: Signs and symptoms occur when blood lead levels >70mcg/dL
Wrist drop is the earliest sign

questions.solution:
The signs and symptoms of lead poisoning occur only when the blood lead levels exceed 70mcg/dL, which is known as the threshold phenomenon.

Lead poisoning is also known as plumbism/ Saturnism/ painter's colic.

questions.text: You are screening the workers in a battery manufacturing factory for exposure to lead. Which of the following screening test will you use?
questions.solution:
The screening test used for estimating lead exposure is the measurement of coproporphyrin in urine.

Diagnosis of lead poisoning

Laboratory parameter Value Remarks
Coproporphyrin in urine >150 mcg/L Screening test- indicates exposure
Aminolevulinic acid (ALA) in urine >5 mg/L Indicates lead absorption
Lead in blood >70 mcg/dL Clinical symptoms appear
Lead in urine 0.8 mg/L Indicates lead absorption
Basophilic stippling of RBCs   Sensitive indicator

Note: Cotinine is the primary metabolite of nicotine and is currently considered the best biomarker for tobacco smoke exposure (both active and passive).

questions.text: Barosinusitis is likely to be seen in which of the following patients?

choices.text: A person who is suffering from mountain sickness
A patient Infected by gas-forming bacteria
A patient diagnosed with Aspergillus sinusitis
A diver who developed decompression sickness

questions.solution:
Barosinusitis occurs in decompression sickness or Caisson's disease. It is due to the sudden expansion of air in the sinuses.

It can be seen in:

  • Divers who ascend rapidly from deep-sea (high pressure) to the surface of the earth (low pressure)
  • Pilots of unpressurized aircraft or mountaineers who rapidly ascended from the surface of the earth (high-pressure zone) to a high altitude (low-pressure zone)

Under high pressure, gases get compressed, and their solubility increases. When a person is in deep-sea (high-pressure zone) for a long time, an increased amount of nitrogen gets dissolved in his body. When he suddenly comes back to the surface (atmospheric pressure or a low-pressure zone), the solubility of gases decreases and they escape from the dissolved state forming nitrogen bubbles.

These bubbles can cause sudden expansion of air in various parts of the body such as the middle ear (barotitis), sinuses (barosinusitis), beneath teeth (barodontalgia), intestinal loops (abdominal distension), and emphysema. 

Nitrogen bubbles can also cause chokes (dyspnoea), bends (joint pain), and prickles (nerve irritation).

The definitive treatment for Caisson's disease is recompression.

questions.text: Workers working at which of the following industries require periodical examination on a daily basis?
questions.solution:
Workers handling irritant chemicals like dichromates require periodical examination on a daily basis.

Most occupational exposures require an annual periodical examination. Certain exposures like lead, radon, and dyes require monthly periodical examination.

questions.text: Serial chest X-rays of an elderly man reveal progressive massive fibrosis. Which of the following pneumoconiosis is associated with this?
questions.solution:
Progressive massive fibrosis (PMF) is associated with anthracosis. PMF classically develops in anthracosis and silicosis.

Exposure to coal dust causes progressive lung injury called anthracosis. Initially, it manifests as simple coal worker pneumoconiosis, which occurs after exposure for 10–12 years and is reversible. Later, it can progress to progressive massive fibrosis (PMF) which is irreversible.

questions.text: Bronchoalveolar lavage from a patient with pneumoconiosis showed Micropolyspora faeni. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Farmer's lung is a hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by thermophilic actinomycetes like Saccharopolyspora rectivirgula (formerly known as Micropolyspora faeni). It occurs due to inhalation of moldy hay and grains causing an immunological reaction.

Woodworker's lung is a hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by Alternaria species, and Bacillus subtilis in persons exposed to oak, cedar, pine, and mahogany dust.

Bird fancier's lung is caused by proteins derived from birds like pigeons and parakeets in persons exposed to their feathers and droppings.

Malt worker's lung is caused by Aspergillus species in persons exposed to barley.

questions.text: Which of the following does not belong to the 4 P's of occupational dermatitis?
questions.solution:
Post-selection check-up does not belong to the 4 P's of occupational dermatitis.

The 4 P's help in the prevention of occupational dermatitis, which include:

  • Pre-selection check-up
  • Protection 
  • Personal hygiene
  • Periodic inspection

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about occupational cancer?

choices.text: Age of incidence is same as compared to general population for the same cancer
The localization of the tumor is variable within a particular industry
The most common occupational cancer is squamous cell carcinoma
Onset of cancer does not occur after the person has left the industry

questions.solution:
The most common occupational cancer is squamous cell carcinoma of the skin. It is associated with exposure to radiation, dyes, and coal tar.

In occupational cancers, the age of incidence of cancer is earlier than that in the general population, affected by the same cancer type. The onset of cancer can occur even after leaving the industry. The localization of the cancer is remarkably constant for a particular industry.

questions.text: Cystoscopy performed on a patient with painless hematuria showed a fungating mass in the bladder. Exposure to all of the following agents can cause this disease except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bladder carcinoma. Benzol does not cause bladder cancer, it causes leukemia. 

Bladder carcinoma is associated with exposure to aniline dyes like benzidine, beta-naphthylamines, auramine, magenta, and drugs like cyclophosphamide.

questions.text: A young woman is being evaluated for infertility. She gives a history of being employed in the printing industry. Exposure to which of the following is likely to cause this situation?
questions.solution:
A woman working in the printing industry is likely to suffer from infertility due to lead toxicity. 

More industrial workers are exposed to lead than to any other toxic metal. Occupational exposure to lead is seen in several industries including the manufacturing of storage batteries, glass, shipbuilding, printing, potteries, and rubber industries. 

The effects of lead poisoning include abdominal colic, blue-line on the gums (Burton's line), stippling of red cells, anemia, wrist & foot drop, headache, and convulsions. In young or pregnant women, prolonged lead exposure can cause miscarriage, stillbirth, premature birth, and low birth weight.

The World Day for Safety and Health at Work conducted on April 28 every year promotes the prevention of occupational accidents and diseases globally.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a personal protective equipment?
questions.solution:
A lab coat is not a personal protective equipment.

Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) are:

  • Gloves – protect hands.
  • Gowns/ aprons – protect skin and clothing.
  • Masks protect the mouth/nose and respirators protect the respiratory tract from airborne infectious agents.
  • Goggles – protect eyes.
  • Face shields – protect face, mouth, nose, and eyes.
